"Utility" is a vague concept and suggests that the behaviours aren't attached to any particular concept. I don't think that's true. We're finding PDRs in and adding them to some particular thing, probably a PDR database? We should think of behaviours in terms of the data that they're associated with and name them accordingly. With that perspective the concept of "utility" things is unnecessary.
nitpick: Capitalisation.
Done
Ack
The space here should be removed.
Done
Not just a host, right? Should be fixed throughout the rest of the commit message.
Done

This addresses *what* the patch is doing, which we can tend to see from the diff. The commit message must explain the *why*. The previous paragraph gets to the why, I don't think this one adds much value.
Ack

I have some concerns about the naming and boolean combinations in the new APIs. There are also problems with use of `assert()`.

I've made note of a few nitpicks as well.

Requiring boolean values in an API are a bit of an anti-pattern on a couple of fronts. The first is that often sets of booleans allow more states than are valid. Are all four combinations valid for this function?

The second is how the function might be invoked at the call-site:

```
pldm_entity_association_tree_add_if_remote(..., false, true);
```

Using booleans often forces us to remember which way around the parameters go, as we can't tell from the values. This starts to get into the territory of Rusty's API scale:

1. [How Do I Make This Hard to Misuse?](https://ozlabs.org/~rusty/index.cgi/tech/2008-03-30.html)
2. [What If I Don't Actually Like My Users?](https://ozlabs.org/~rusty/index.cgi/tech/2008-04-01.html)

If we must have boolean parameters it is nicer to provide named constants. Enums in APIs are often unhelpful because prior to C23 we can't control their size. This in-turn makes it hard to correctly do FFI from other languages. However, we can define constants with macros.

Given that we're passing in the boolean `is_remote`, we already know if the entity is remote before we call the function. It feels like there's a less complex API design that should work here, or the `_if_remote` suffix could do with some workshopping.

As discussed with you Andrew over the call, the 2 booleans - 
is_remote is used to indicate if the entity is BMC owned or of remote endpoint owned.
is_update_container_id is used to indicate if the container id of the entity needs to be updated or not.

We handle 3 different combinations,
1. Both are false - when it is the parent node in the tree example: - https://github.com/ibm-openbmc/pldm/blob/1050/libpldmresponder/pdr_state_sensor.hpp#L136
2. is_remote is false and update_container_id is true - when it is a BMC entity but we have a container id change needed. example: - https://github.com/ibm-openbmc/pldm/blob/1050/libpldmresponder/fru.cpp#L130
3. is_remote is true and update_container_id is false - In IBM PLDM stack talks to two different remote firmware implementations over PLDM, and we had a conflicting requirement to not merge the container ID from one endpoint but merge the container ID from another endpoint. Example: -https://github.com/ibm-openbmc/pldm/blob/1050/host-bmc/host_pdr_handler.cpp#L509
Well, let's see how this goes. If we find a better way to express the behaviour of this function we can change it, given it's marked `LIBPLDM_ABI_TESTING`.
Same concerns as with the function as above.
Ack

No asserts thanks. This must signal an error to the caller by returning.

Please audit and fix this issue throughout the rest of the patch.
Ack
Is this mostly a copy/paste of `pldm_entity_association_tree_add()`? If so, can we instead make `pldm_entity_association_tree_add()` call into this implementation so we don't have twice the code?
This comment remains to be addressed.

This method is not fully a copy/paste of the pldm_entity_association_tree_add() method, there are changes made to the node based on the is_remote and update container_id value before the node is returned from the function.
here -
1. https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/63585/5..7/src/pdr.c#539 
2. https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/63585/5..7/src/pdr.c#544
3. https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/63585/5..7/src/pdr.c#591

Do you have any suggestions on how this could be achieved?
Can you call from `pldm_entity_association_tree_add()` into `pldm_entity_association_tree_add_entities()` with a combination of the boolean arguments to do the right thing?

This cannot be done, as we get the boolean value arguments from the caller APIs. If one of the arguments (say is_update_conatainer_id) is true we need to update the container id given by the caller which is not available via this `pldm_entity_association_tree_add()` method.

Do you have any other suggestions:)
I've done the work to merge both. Can you please inspect the result? The test suite passes but I'm not sure how much coverage we get.
This should be declared static?
Done
This is the same as the condition below on lines 974-976. Please factor it out.
Done

Again here, please prefix the patch subject with the affected subsystem. The subject might then look like:

`pdr: Add APIs for creating and locating remote PDRs`
Done

I have some misgivings about the function naming and parameters still. But before that, I'd like to see the two similar implementations unified. Once that's done we can address the problem of whether several boolean parameters are really what we need.

I also think we must put some effort in to keep the unit tests maintainable. The current code makes it very difficult to keep track of what properties are being upheld
Should we be updating the doxygen commentary for this function to indicate that the PDR it adds will be a local PDR?
Done

The immediate problem I have with the name of this function is that it suggests that if `is_remote` is false the PDR will not be added. As far as I'm aware that's not the behaviour provided by the implementation.
Done
This can be `const`?
Done
This can be `const`?
No, we change the entity container id.
Can we please `assert(out != NULL && *out == NULL)`?
Done
Done
For readability, please extract these tests into intermediate variables.
Done

Is this a minimal test? I really cannot tell what properties are meant to be upheld here, there's just too much going on.

Please try to write tests demonstrating each property being upheld as a separate, minimal unit test function.
Ack, I have made changes to the test case.
Hi Pavithra, I've marked this as -1 because must use `LIBPLDM_ABI_TESTING` for now, and not `LIBPLDM_ABI_STABLE`.

This must be `LIBPLDM_ABI_TESTING`. I acknowledge that how to choose an annotation wasn't documented anywhere, but I've set about rectifying that now:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/64074
Ack
This must be `LIBPLDM_ABI_TESTING`, as above.
Done
